In Green, D. M. (Ed.), Amphibians in Decline: Canadian Studies of a Global Problem. Society for the Study of Amphibians and Reptiles, Herpetological Conservation, Number 1, St. Louis, Missouri.
Lannoo, M. 2005. M. Lannoo (Ed.), Amphibian Declines. The Conservation Status of United States Species, University of California Press, Berkeley, CA (2005), p. 1094
Petranka, J. W. 1998. Salamanders of the United States and Canada. Washington DC: Smithsonian Inst. Press.
Green, D.M., L.A. Weir, G.S. Casper, and M.J. Lannoo. 2013.  North American Amphibians: Distribution and Diversity.  University of California Press. Berkeley, California. 340 pp.

NatureServe. 2016. NatureServe Explorer: An online encyclopedia of life [web application]. Version 7.1. NatureServe, Arlington, Virginia. Available http://explorer.natureserve.org. (Accessed: March 22, 2016).

Llewellyn, R. L., and C. R. Peterson. 1998. Distribution, relative abundance, and habitat associations of amphibians and reptiles on Craig Mountain, Idaho. Idaho Bureau of Land Management, Technical Bulletin 95-15, Boise, Idaho.
Beneski, J. T. Jr., E. J. Zalisko, and J. H. J. Larsen. 1986. Demography and migratory patterns of the eastern long-toed salamander, Ambystoma macrodactylum columbianum. Copeia 1986:398-408.

Hamilton, G. B., C. R. Peterson, and W. A. Wall. 1998. Distribution and habitat relationships of amphibians on the Potlach Corporation operating area in northern Idaho. Potlach Corporation, Unpublished report, Lewiston, Idaho.

Leonard, W. P., H. A. Brown, L. L. C. Jones, K. R. McAllister, and R. M. Storm. 1993. Amphibians of Washington and Oregon. Seattle Audobon Society, Trailside Series. Seattle Audobon Society, Seattle, Washington.
Russell, R. W., and J. D. Anderson. 1956. A disjunct population of the long-nosed salamander from the coast of California. Herpetologica 12:137-140
Leonard, W. P., and O. R. Klaus. 1994. Western long-toed salamander demographics and oviposition in a small vernal wetland of the Puget Sound lowlands. Northwest Science 68:135.

Pilliod, D. S. 2001. Ecology and conservation of high elevation amphibian populations in historically fishless watersheds with introduced trout. Ph. D. dissertation. Department of Biological Sciences, Idaho State University, Pocatello, Idaho.
Crother, B. I. (ed.) 2012. Standard Common and Current Scientific Names for North American Amphibians, Turtles, Reptiles, and Crocodilians, Seventh Edition. Herpetological Circular 39: 1-92.
Stebbins, R.C. 2003. A field guide to western reptiles and amphibians.  Third Edition. Houghton Mifflin, Boston.
habitat_description:
The distribution of this species extends from the Alaskan Peninsula through British Columbia, south into Washington, Oregon, and the Sierra Nevada of California; populations also occur across the Rocky Mountains into eastern Alberta, central Idaho, and western Montana, but also some isolated populations in central California and southeastern Oregon (Lannoo 2005; Petranka 1998; Russell and Anderson 1956; Stebbins 2003). These isolated populations are currently present in coastal California around Monterey Bay (Green et al. 2013).
Breeding habitat includes a wide variety of damp places including seeps (Hamilton et al. 1998), backwaters of slow flowing streams (Beneski et al. 1986; Hamilton et al. 1998; Llewelyn and Peterson 1998), ephemeral low elevation ponds (Leonard and Klaus 1994), but also large and permanent bodies of water at higher elevations (Pilliod 2001). Other sites reported include highly disturbed and newly formed shallow pools (Beneski et al. 1986; Monello and Wright 1999). 
As adults, this species occupies a wide variety of habitats including sagebrush steppes, semiarid grassland, alpine meadows, humid coniferous forests, beaver ponds, dry oak woodlands, rocky shorelines, subalpine lakes, pastures, and even disturbed areas like residential green areas (Lannoo 2005; Hamilton et al. 1998; Leonard et al. 1993). It is important to mention that migratory movements for this species does not only occur over obvious suitable habitats (Beneski et al. 1986). 
Adults are described as subterranean when not in breeding season; cover is provided by logs, rodent burrows, bark, rocks, rotten wood, all usually within 100 meters from the water (Stebbins 1966, 2003; Powell et al. 1997). 

Larvae may avoid predation by hiding under bottom detritus, logs, and aquatic vegetation (Petranka 1998).
